title: Can you trust your ears? (audio illusions)

multiple-choice.question: What is the Mcgurk effect in relation to human perception?

options.label: A
options.text: A phenomenon where visuals can alter what we believe we're seeing.

options.label: B
options.text: A phenomenon where visuals can alter what we believe we're hearing.

options.label: C
options.text: A phenomenon where sounds can alter what we believe we're seeing.

options.label: D
options.text: A phenomenon where sounds can alter what we believe we're hearing.

multiple-choice.question: In the experiment with the flashing circle, what altered the perceived vision?
What is the tritone paradox, and how does it work?

options.label: A
options.text: An auditory illusion where two tones are played, and the brain prefers the higher frequency.

options.label: B
options.text: An auditory illusion where two tones are played, and the brain prefers the lower frequency.

options.label: C
options.text: An auditory illusion where two tones are played, and the brain has a preference based on geography and language.

options.label: D
options.text: An auditory illusion where one tone is played, and the brain perceives it as two different tones.

multiple-choice.question: Who is the creator of the tritone paradox illusion?
What is the main factor that influences an individual's perception of the tritone paradox?
What is the Shepard tone illusion, and how does it work?

options.label: A
options.text: An auditory illusion where multiple sine waves are played, and the brain perceives a continuously descending pitch.

options.label: B
options.text: An auditory illusion where multiple sine waves are played, and the brain perceives a continuously ascending pitch.

options.label: C
options.text: An auditory illusion where one sine wave is played, and the brain perceives a continuously ascending pitch.

options.label: D
options.text: An auditory illusion where one sine wave is played, and the brain perceives a continuously descending pitch.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the Shepard tone illusion create a continuously ascending pitch?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the brain notices the drop in pitch and compensates for it.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the brain doesn't notice the drop in pitch and continues to perceive the ascending pitch.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the sine waves are played in a specific order.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the sine waves are played at a specific frequency.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the discussion of auditory illusions in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To show how our brains can be tricked into perceiving different things.

options.label: B
options.text: To demonstrate the importance of auditory illusions in music.

options.label: C
options.text: To explain how auditory illusions can be used to create music.

options.label: D
options.text: To discuss the role of auditory illusions in shaping our perception of reality.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what can have a profound yet varying effect on our minds?

options.label: C
options.text: In the description of the video

options.label: A
options.text: A charity that provides aid to refugees

options.label: B
options.text: A community organization that provides free meals to those in need

options.label: C
options.text: A research initiative that studies the effects of charitable giving

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.text: If you hear anything over the radio, radio to your parent whether you got to your spot by going left or right

options.label: B
options.text: When you reach an intersection, move off the conveyor and send new copies down the left and right paths

options.label: C
options.text: If you've reached the artifact, radio to your parent whether you got there by going left or right

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the third instruction in the Pathfinder action?

options.label: A
options.text: To tell the parent which way to go to the artifact

options.label: B
options.text: To repeat everything heard over the radio

options.label: C
options.text: To send new copies down the left and right paths

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome of the Pathfinder action?

options.label: A
options.text: An entire network of paths is mapped using just three instructions

options.label: B
options.text: The safe path is not found

options.label: C
options.text: The robots are able to catch up to Ethic and Hedge

options.label: D
options.text: The Node of Memory is not reached

title: If your hands could smell, you‚Äôd be an octopus

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary mechanism by which an octopus's suckers stick to surfaces?
What is the name of the ring-shaped structure in an octopus's sucker that creates a water-tight seal?
What happens to the skin of an octopus's suckers every few weeks?
What is a unique feature of an octopus's suckers besides their ability to stick to surfaces?
Why do octopuses have a large number of neurons in their arms?
What is the role of the central brain in an octopus's movement?

options.label: A
options.text: It controls the movement of each arm

options.label: B
options.text: It tells the arms how fast to move

options.label: C
options.text: It determines the direction of movement

options.label: D
options.text: It has no role in movement

multiple-choice.question: How do the arms of an octopus determine how to reach for an object?

options.label: B
options.text: Each arm receives instructions from the central brain

options.label: C
options.text: The arms receive feedback from sensory receptors

options.label: D
options.text: Each arm has its own instructions

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique feature of an octopus's nervous system?

options.label: A
options.text: It has a large central brain

options.label: B
options.text: It has a small number of neurons

options.label: C
options.text: Two-thirds of its neurons are in its arms

options.label: D
options.text: It has no peripheral nervous system

multiple-choice.question: How do the suckers and arms of an octopus work together to create a well-coordinated movement?

options.label: A
options.text: The suckers send signals to the central brain, which controls the arms

options.label: B
options.text: The arms send signals to the suckers, which adjust their grip

options.label: C
options.text: The suckers and arms work independently to create a coordinated movement

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the podcast hosted by Amy Standen mentioned in the transcript?

title: The importance of setting in a story

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's initial attitude towards the setting in a story?

options.label: A
options.text: The speaker thinks the setting is crucial to the plot.

options.label: B
options.text: The speaker believes the setting is somewhat important.

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker thinks the setting is not as important as the characters and plot.

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker believes the setting is irrelevant to the story.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker use as an example to illustrate how the setting can inform the plot?

options.label: A
options.text: A character named Todd who is sweating while running a race.

options.label: B
options.text: A character named Todd who is sweating in different settings, such as a track, a classroom, or a ship.

options.label: C
options.text: A character named Odysseus who is trapped in a cave with a cyclops.

options.label: D
options.text: A character named Todd who is exploring a new city.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what can the setting reveal in a story?

options.label: C
options.text: The plot, conflicts, mood, and themes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's point about the setting in the story of Odysseus and the cyclops?

options.label: A
options.text: The cave setting was chosen randomly by the author.

options.label: B
options.text: The cave setting was key to the plot, conflict, mood, and themes.

options.label: C
options.text: The cave setting was only important for the plot.

options.label: D
options.text: The cave setting was only important for the mood.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker compare the setting to in terms of its importance to the story?

options.label: A
options.text: A score in a movie scene.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice to writers when choosing a setting?

options.label: A
options.text: Choose a random place and put the story there.

options.label: B
options.text: Choose a setting that fits the mood and themes of the story.

options.label: C
options.text: Choose a setting that is only important for the plot.

options.label: D
options.text: Choose a setting that is only important for the characters.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's point about the relationship between the setting and the mood?

options.label: A
options.text: The setting has no impact on the mood.

options.label: B
options.text: The setting can inform the mood, but not the themes.

options.label: C
options.text: The setting can inform the mood and themes.

options.label: D
options.text: The mood is more important than the setting.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's example of a setting that might evoke a mood of hopefulness and excitement?

options.label: B
options.text: A Cliffs side drive with a nice new ride under bright blue skies.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's point about the importance of the setting in a story?

options.label: A
options.text: The setting is not as important as the characters and plot.

options.label: B
options.text: The setting is somewhat important, but not crucial.

options.label: C
options.text: The setting is crucial to the story, like a score is to a movie scene.

options.label: D
options.text: The setting is only important for the themes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final point about the setting, using a series of analogies?

options.label: A
options.text: A story needs a setting like a character needs dialogue.

options.label: B
options.text: A story needs a setting like a song needs a beat, or a bird needs a beak.

options.label: C
options.text: A story needs a setting like a plot needs a twist.

options.label: D
options.text: A story needs a setting like a theme needs a statement.

title: Why do India and China have so many people?

multiple-choice.question: What is the combined population of India and China?
Over the last 300 years, how many people did India and China each add to their populations?
What is the main reason why India and China have more people today compared to other countries?

options.label: A
options.text: They have been growing at a faster rate than the rest of the world.

options.label: B
options.text: They had a larger population a few hundred years ago when the world began its period of modern population growth.

options.label: C
options.text: They have more land area than other countries.

options.label: D
options.text: They have better access to healthcare.

multiple-choice.question: What are the two most plausible explanations for why India and China had a large population when they started their rapid growth?
What is a common characteristic among the 10 most populated countries in the world?

options.label: A
options.text: They all have a relatively small amount of farmland.

options.label: B
options.text: They all have a relatively large amount of farmland.

options.label: C
options.text: They all have a high GDP per capita.

options.label: D
options.text: They all have a low population density.

multiple-choice.question: Where did the domestication of plants and animals essentially start?
Why are countries like Pakistan and Bangladesh unable to contain as many people as India and China?

options.label: D
options.text: They have less access to healthcare.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the initiative at the University of Minnesota that is working to figure out how to keep feeding the world's growing population without harming the planet?
What is the main goal of the IPUMS Terra project?

options.label: A
options.text: To integrate global population data with data on the economy.

options.label: B
options.text: To integrate global population data with data on the environment.

options.label: C
options.text: To integrate global population data with data on healthcare.

options.label: D
options.text: To integrate global population data with data on education.

options.label: B

options.text: Because he wanted to show off

options.label: A
options.text: He tried to find ways to work around it

options.label: D
options.text: He tried to compensate by holding the pen tighter

options.label: B
options.text: To take medication to reduce the shake

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: He found a new approach to art that worked with his shake

options.label: C
options.text: He became frustrated and gave up on art

options.label: D
options.text: He saw no change in his art

options.text: To take a break from art

options.label: B
options.text: To try new techniques and mediums

options.label: A
options.text: He became frustrated and gave up on art

options.label: B
options.text: He saw no change in his art

options.label: C
options.text: He found a new sense of creativity and freedom

options.label: D
options.text: He became overwhelmed by the limitations

multiple-choice.question: What was the concept behind the speaker's "Goodbye Art" project?

options.label: A
options.text: To create art that would last forever

options.label: B
options.text: To create art that would be destroyed after its creation

options.label: C
options.text: To create art that would be sold to the highest bidder

options.label: D
options.text: To create art that would be displayed in a gallery

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker learn from his "Goodbye Art" project?

options.label: C
options.text: The liberation of creating art without attachment to the outcome

options.label: D
options.text: The need for perfection in art

options.label: B

options.label: C
